reviewText:
Do not purchase.  Hopefully you are reading this prior to buying the game and not after like I did. If you purchase this you wont be able to play it anyway.  so even at $0.99 it is a waste of money. Burn the dollar if you want to get actual entertainment value out of it becuase you will not be able to play this game as the CD keys are mostly broken and you will spend hours of your time trying to get a dollar game to work only to have it not.

As the users her have said steam does not give 2 Sh*ts about the issues with their games and will keep on happily taking your money for a game that doesn't work and they will do nothing about it it.  Being that they are too big to fail and one of the only viable options out there, F*cking over a small percentage of the community doesn't really matter to them as it wont have any impact.

So do yourself a favor, no matter how fun the game looks, don't purchase it, be sure to read reviews before you buy things and game on!

reviewText:
There isn't much of a game here, but I'm going to review it anyways.

First off, this is another Capcom game that uses Securom, but unlike Dark Void before it, it doesn't suffer the Securom fate of not finding the cd key in their database.  But thats about all the 'good news' this game has going for it.

The game uses Gamespy for it's multiplayer, and well, it doesn't exsist anymore, so you can't play the multiplayer and considering what little single player there is, there is pretty much no game left.  There is seven tiny single player missions.  None of them are really good.  There is a few different difficulty levels, but playing the 'campaign' through on easy, there wasn't really anything there that made me want to challenge myself on harder difficulties.

Don't buy this game, don't make the mistake I did.

reviewText:
I have yet to defeat the first Boss battle; SecuROM. I've tried countless tactics and even resorted to looking up cheat codes.

This is a prime example of how not to do DRM. I am a big proponent of good DRM when it is used as a function to benifit both the developers and the consumer (Steam is a great example). When DRM offers consumers no benifit, and becomes an onerous task such as with this game it defeats the purpose of the DRM. It is games like this one that encourage otherwise willing and paying customers to resort to pirating the game just to rid themselves of the challenge of an otherwise simple task; launching the game.

-999/10 - Would not DRM again.

reviewText:
Short answer: Great game IF AND ONLY IF you use some server to emulate GameSpy.

Long answer:
The game by itself is very fun, and requires coordination on a fast paced strategy. Single player game can be quite frustrating as you depend heavily on AI to cooperate with you, and it probably won't requiring many trials to win even easy maps.
Unfortunately multiplayer was heavily damaged by GameSpy shutdown, and the game feels broken if you're not authenticated on a server, as you can't even use the map editor. Also, the best part of this game is the multiplayer, and that will require a third party server to authenticate. Do not buy the game unless you're savvy enough to use a GameSpy emulator. I used qtracker with my friends and we played smoothly over LAN. It worked great, we had great fun. Totally worth the R$ 1.69 and the fiddling to make it work on a different server.

reviewText:
The game works for me. Steam should give you a 16-digit alpha-numeric code when you purchase. Put that in the Securom (grey pop up) box in the blank line. Don't worry about the other long code (25 or 30 chars), it's generated by them to verify the game. After successfully going through this process once, you should be good. It won't happen every time you launch.

The Gamespy servers are off, so there's no multiplayer, leaderboards, or map generator, which does suck, but you'll be able to get a dollar's worth from the 21 pre-built scenarios.

If Steam could somehow separate the Gamespy servers from the game, even just to open the map generator, that would add a lot. Single players could generate their own maps and choose the number of AI players and win conditions. Is that remotely possible from a programming standpoint?

reviewText:
// Age of Booty an RTS Game: //
// Schuitje82 - Small Review //

I love this game... why... the soundtracks are amazing.... :D

It's a simple RTS game because of the way it plays.
You just move a boot around and with a simple click you conquer island and beat your enemies.
Between battles it’s possible you need to recover at your main base or need to get back for some upgrades. So it’s not about who get’s first and winm no it’s about how you play the game.
Game support many stages pre-build stages and gives a small variation to the game.
Sometimes you play against 2 CPU’s or yu have a CPU as a friend who helps you with the battle.
Or there are many island to conquer so you run between them to defend and keep them yours.

I’ve played this game many hours on console and makes this game less fun on PC is that it has no local co-op multiplayer and the online servers are offline.
So keep in mind this will be a singleplayer game only :(

It's a very fun and addictive video game with a few options to play with or against the PC.
Only downside is de securom security activation as the key you need to enter first time use.
I hate this because we have steam :) …

Score 6.5 / 10.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/21600

== For more reviews go to www.gamegrin.com ==
== Please don't forget to like my reviews ==

reviewText: I enjoyed this game.  The controls are simple but the game is entertaining.  I know others have had problems getting the game to run, so be careful - I did not have any trouble.  It is a bit simple for my tastes, so I tend to play other games, but I keep thinking I should come back to play this one for a while.  I like the simplicity of roaming the seas, capturing and holding ports, and generally just taking over the map.  It is real time, but has elements similar to board games.  You can spend resources to upgrade your ship or the defenses of individual ports.  There are some team maps where you are partnered with AI team mates.

reviewText: I read a bunch of negative reviews of this game. The game itself is what you expect. It is not the greatest game out there by far, but I purchased it for one dollar so i am not upset at all. The big thing i read was that the game does not work. I started the game up, typed my 16 digit key code in and the game started up. It asked to type it again and the game started right up. I plundered the first mission and won. The game seems very short, especially since the online is no more. For the price I paid, and the game DOES work, it was worth it. I would recommend this game for the price i paid, but for no more that that due to how short and lack of online.

reviewText: A fun, relatively simple strategy game definitely worth checking out while it's only $1.24. I wouldn't say it's worth the full $4.99, but opinions vary. You control a pirate ship and along with your ally ships (who you do not control), you try to take most/all of the towns on the map, depending on the victory requirements. Neutral ships carry curses, which are similar to spells in Age of Mythology. Curses can send a whirpool under an enemy ship, plunder resources from the enemy, and other effects. You manage three resources -- Gold, Wood, and Ale. These are needed to upgrade your ship. Cannons, Speed, and Armor can be upgraded. Your towns can also be improved to help defend themselves, and this becomes more important to tip the balance in your favor on harder maps.\n\nOverall, an enjoyable game for casual strategy fans. I have not attempted multiplayer, and have had no trouble with the DRM like other reviews.

reviewText:
Steam code worked fine, i think the other guys just don't know how to write something down correctly w/o using Copy/Paste....
Gameplay is great.  For some reason i thought that this was a turn-based game, so was a little surprised to find it's not, but it's still 21 levels of great fun.  Some big cons though, as GameSpy is dead:
-Multi-player doesn't work.
-Map Creator doesn't work.
-Leaderboards don't work.
So if you're going to buy it, buy it for the 21 pre-set levels for 0.99 and no more.
The lack of in-game music is kind of odd, but i just play my own.

reviewText: Age of Booty is a fun little game where you take on the roll of a pirate who has to go do various missions with little back stories. I think it's pretty good fun. Each little mission only takes between 5 - 20 minutes. They also aren't super heavy on the story or action type stuff so setting it down for a few days/weeks and coming back isn't a problem. reviewText:
This is a fantastic multiplayer adverserial game and deserves to be repaired, but alas, Capcom is not interested.
However there is a LAN fix which will restore the fun to your local LAN.

http://aluigi.altervista.org/papers/gs_login_server.zip

This link, courtesy of Svond, contains a gamespy emulator and instructions on how to use. Be aware that one of your LAN buddies will need to be ip-network-router savvy to understand the instructions, and the procedure fix it did require some router option settings fiddling.

enjoy and goodluck.

reviewText:
As other reviewers have commented, don't bother buying this.
That said, if you want the detailed explanation, here goes:

Once you get passed (if you ever do) all the bologne regarding the SecureRom & CD-Key enforcement, you'll come to a menu that has only two working choices: 'Challenges' & 'Help and Options'
Challenges (also known as: we couldnt call it single player because there is almost NO content) are rediculously short and (suppoosedly) teaches you the merits of multiplayer -- even though there IS NO LONGER MULTPLAYER...
Help & Options explains how to use the Map Editor, which you can't use without logging into the Gamespy servers (which no longer exist), as well as allowing you to change your resolution and choose between full screen or no.
This is arguably the best feature of the game in it's current state. Yes, you read that correctly, changing the resolution of the game is most fun I had in 'Age of Booty'.

Since the game is no longer purchasable on Steam, you're -- yes you, reading this! -- in luck because you don't have the luxury of wasting hard earned money on this title.
I on the other hand did waste my green on it & have set-up a Go Fund Me account to recoup my losses on purchasing this absolute piece of garbage software.

You can find my Go Fund Me at: https://www.gofundme.com/givemebackmymoneyyougamespyporkpies

Please give me your money so I feel better, Cheers!
